openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Syria was initially primarily based on agriculture during the country's early years.
• The Syrian economy experienced significant deterioration following the onset of the Syrian civil war in March 2011.
• The information presented in the article requires updating to reflect recent events or newly available data as of June 2025.
• Since the establishment of the First Syrian Republic in 1946, Syria's economy has experienced numerous structural and other significant changes.
• During World War II, the presence of Allied forces stimulated Syrian commerce by providing markets for agriculture, textiles, and other locally manufactured goods.
• Despite this stimulation, Syria lacked the necessary infrastructure and resources to achieve sustained economic prosperity during this period.

• Agriculture played a central role in the Syrian economy and became a catalyst for industrial expansion as landowners reinvested profits from agricultural exports into agroindustrial and related urban enterprises.
• The rural population, primarily working under land tenure and sharecropping systems, gained minimal benefits from the agriculturally driven economic growth experienced in the 1950s.

• Syria's brief political union with Egypt from 1958 to 1961, known as the United Arab Republic, alongside the rise of the Baath Party as the dominant political force in the 1960s, significantly altered Syria's economic orientation and development strategy.
• The historical development of Syria’s real GDP per capita since 1820 reflects these economic transformations and structural shifts over time.

• By the mid-1960s, Syria's economic policy had firmly adopted a socialist direction characterized by government-sponsored land reform and the nationalization of major industries and foreign investments.

• The Syrian state increased its control over economic decision-making through centralized planning and strict regulation of commercial transactions, leading to a significant loss of skilled workers, administrators, and capital.

• Political upheavals during this period undermined the confidence of landowners, merchants, and industrialists, yet the state successfully carried out large-scale development projects aimed at expanding industry, agriculture, and infrastructure.
• In the 1970s, Syria experienced high rates of economic growth, partly driven by the dramatic rise in world oil prices between 1973 and 1974, which boosted production from domestic oil refineries.
• The increase in prices for agricultural and oil exports, combined with the state's limited economic liberalization policies, further stimulated economic growth during the decade.
• Syria’s economic boom was also supported by increased remittances from Syrians working in oil-rich Arab states, as well as higher levels of Arab and other foreign aid.
• By the end of the 1970s, the Syrian economy had transitioned from a traditional agrarian base to one dominated by the service, industrial, and commercial sectors.

• Massive government expenditures were directed toward the development of irrigation systems, electricity, water supply, road construction, expansion of health services, education in rural areas, and the establishment of irisin plants, all contributing to increased prosperity.
• Despite these advances, the Syrian economy remained heavily dependent on foreign aid and grants to finance growing budgetary and trade deficits.

• Syria’s position as a front-line state in the Arab-Israeli conflict made it vulnerable to the instability of Middle East politics, necessitating reliance on Arab aid transfers and Soviet assistance to support escalating defense expenditures.
• By the mid-1980s, Syria's economic climate shifted from a period of prosperity to one of austerity due to multiple adverse factors.
• The collapse of Syria's economic boom was triggered by the rapid fall in world oil prices, which significantly reduced export revenues.
• Agricultural production was negatively impacted by drought conditions during this period.
• Worker remittances to Syria also declined, further weakening the economy.
• Arab aid levels decreased as a result of economic retrenchment in oil-producing states and Syria's political support for Iran during the Iran-Iraq War.
• Between 1982 and 1989, Syria experienced a 22% decline in real per capita GDP, indicating a substantial economic contraction.
• In response, the Syrian government implemented austerity measures including sharp reductions in government spending and import cutbacks.
• The government also encouraged increased private sector participation and foreign investment as part of economic recovery efforts.
• An anticorruption campaign was launched targeting smugglers and black-market money changers to improve economic governance.
• Despite these measures, massive defense expenditures continued to divert significant resources away from productive economic investments.
• By the late 1980s, Syria faced frequent spot shortages of basic commodities, reflecting supply chain and production challenges.
• Industrial production operated far below capacity, hindered by routine power outages that disrupted manufacturing activities.
• Foreign exchange reserves declined sharply, exacerbating financial instability.
• The trade deficit widened, further straining the country’s balance of payments.
• Real gross domestic product (GDP) growth slowed as economic difficulties compounded throughout the decade.

• Although the government introduced limited reforms to address the escalating crisis, the severity of Syria's economic problems necessitated a radically restructured economic policy to improve future performance.

• In 1990, the Assad government implemented a series of economic reforms aimed at liberalizing the economy, although the Syrian economy remained highly regulated throughout the 1990s and into the 2000s.
• The Syrian economy experienced strong growth during the 1990s and early 2000s, with Syria’s per capita GDP reaching US$4,058 in 2010.
• Authoritative GDP data for Syria is unavailable after 2012 due to the outbreak of the Syrian civil war.

• Upon assuming power in 2000, Bashar al-Assad prioritized modernizing and opening the Syrian economy, emphasizing the need to reform the regulatory environment and industrial base, activate and encourage the private sector, remove bureaucratic investment obstacles, increase job opportunities, qualify cadres, improve education, and expand information technology.

• The neoliberal economic reforms under Bashar al-Assad contributed to increased trade and revitalization of the private sector but were accompanied by rising economic inequality, declining quality of public services, and increasing corruption.
• These negative social and economic consequences of the reforms contributed to the outbreak of protests in 2011.

• In February 2011, the Syrian Agricultural Workers Union publicly criticized state mismanagement and the removal of input subsidies, stating these factors worsened the impact of drought on Syria’s agricultural sector.
• Prior to the civil war, agriculture and oil were the two main pillars of the Syrian economy, together accounting for approximately 50% of GDP.
• Agriculture alone accounted for about 26% of GDP and employed 25% of the total labor force before the civil war.

• Poor climatic conditions and severe drought significantly damaged the agricultural sector, reducing its share of GDP to about 17% in 2008, down from 20.4% in 2007, according to preliminary data from Syria’s Central Bureau of Statistics.
• Despite declining oil production, higher crude oil prices helped offset losses by increasing budgetary revenues and export receipts during this period.

• Since the outbreak of the Syrian Civil War, Syria's economy has been significantly impacted by economic sanctions that restrict trade with multiple entities, including the Arab League, Australia, Canada, the European Union, and specific European countries such as Albania, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Norway, Serbia, and Switzerland, as well as Georgia, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Turkey, and the United States.

• The scope of sanctions against Syria was further expanded by the United States through the Caesar Syria Civilian Protection Act, which came into force in June 2020, intensifying economic restrictions on the country.

• The civil war has caused extensive destruction and displacement, devastating Syria's economy; by the end of 2013, the United Nations estimated the total economic damage from the conflict at $143 billion.
• In 2018, the World Bank reported that approximately one-third of Syria's housing stock and half of its health and education facilities had been destroyed due to the ongoing conflict.
• The World Bank also estimated that from 2011 to 2016, Syria suffered a cumulative GDP loss totaling $226 billion as a direct consequence of the civil war.
• The Syrian economy experienced conflict-related hyperinflation, with the annual inflation rate becoming one of the highest globally.

• The Syrian pound, the national currency, experienced a dramatic devaluation, plummeting from LS 47 to the US dollar before the 2011 uprising to over LS 3,000 to the dollar by mid-2020, signaling a severe economic downturn.

• The rapid depreciation of the Syrian pound led to skyrocketing prices for basic goods, with some staple items disappearing from the market as both merchants and the public struggled to cope with the escalating cost of living.
• In 2022, Syria joined the Chinese Belt and Road Initiative, a strategic move expected to assist in rebuilding the country’s war-damaged infrastructure and reviving its economy.

• Following the end of Bashar al-Assad’s regime and the civil war, the interim Syrian government appointed Maysaa Sabreen as the governor of the central bank on December 30, 2024, marking the first time a woman has held this position in Syria’s history.

• Prior to this appointment, on December 10, 2024, Basel Abdul Hannan was named Minister of the Economy; in this capacity, he announced plans to implement market liberalization reforms aimed at dismantling the existing import-export control system and transitioning Syria toward a free-market economic model.

• During a meeting with the Damascus Chambers of Commerce, Minister Basel Abdul Hannan outlined intentions to remove import restrictions and enable registered businesses to engage in freer trade, signaling a shift toward economic openness and reform.
• During the 1960s, the Syrian government nationalized most major enterprises following socialist principles and implemented economic policies aimed at addressing regional and class disparities.
• Economic reform in Syria has been incremental and gradual, with significant milestones including the legalization of private banking in 2001.
• In 2004, four private banks commenced operations in Syria, marking a notable shift towards financial sector liberalization.
• In August 2004, the Syrian government formed a committee to oversee the establishment of a stock market, indicating efforts to develop capital markets.

• Beyond financial reforms, the Syrian government enacted major changes to rental and tax laws and was reportedly considering similar reforms to the commercial code and other laws affecting property rights (citation needed).
• Syria began producing heavy-grade oil from fields in the northeast since the late 1960s, establishing a domestic oil industry.
• In the early 1980s, Syria discovered light-grade, low-sulphur oil near Deir ez-Zor in eastern Syria, which eliminated the need to import light oil for blending with heavy crude in refineries.
• By 2011, at the onset of the Syrian civil war, oil production had declined to 353,000 barrels per day (bpd), and by 2018, production had plunged further to 24,000 bpd.
• Syria’s oil reserves were gradually depleted and estimated at approximately 2.5 billion barrels by 2018.

• In 1990, the Syrian government established an official parallel exchange rate to incentivize remittances and exports through official channels, which improved the supply of basic commodities and helped contain inflation by removing risk premiums on smuggled goods.
• Foreign aid to Syria in 1997 was estimated at US$199 million.
• The World Bank reported that by July 2004, it had committed a total of US$661 million for 20 operations in Syria, with one investment project remaining active at that time.
• Key economic indicators for Syria over selected years are as follows:
• In 2006, Syria's economy, despite recovering from a severe drought in the late 1990s and an increase in energy export revenues, continued to face significant challenges historically.

• Commerce has been a vital component of the Syrian economy, benefiting from Syria's strategic location along major east–west trade routes, facilitating both traditional industries such as weaving and dried-fruit packing, as well as modern heavy industry.
• From the 1960s through the late 1980s, Syria adopted policies that effectively excluded it from the "global economy," reflecting a period of economic isolationism.
• In late 2001, Syria submitted a formal request to the World Trade Organization (WTO) to begin the accession process, marking a shift towards integration with the global trading system.
• Syria was originally a contracting party to the former General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) but withdrew in 1951 due to Israel's accession to the agreement.
• To comply with WTO rules, Syria would need to amend major elements of its current trade regulations.
• In March 2007, Syria signed an Association Agreement with the European Union aimed at encouraging negotiations for a free trade agreement to be concluded before 2010.
• The majority of Syrian imports consist of raw materials essential for industry and agriculture, as well as equipment and machinery necessary for economic activities.
• Syria’s major exports include crude oil, refined petroleum products, raw cotton, clothing, fruits, and cereal grains, reflecting a diverse export base.
• The Syrian government progressively expanded the application of a more favorable exchange rate used for transactions with neighboring countries.
• In 2001, Syria introduced a quasi-exchange rate for non-commercial transactions, which was broadly aligned with prevailing black market rates to address currency valuation issues.

• Due to underdeveloped domestic capital markets and restricted access to international money and capital markets, Syria’s monetary policy has been constrained by the necessity to finance the fiscal deficit.
• In 2003, Syria lowered interest rates for the first time in 22 years and reduced them again in 2004; however, interest rates remain legally fixed rather than market-determined.
• By 2012, the ongoing Syrian civil war had drastically reduced the value of Syria’s overall exports by two-thirds, from US$12 billion in 2010 to only US$4 billion in 2012.
• Syria’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) declined by over 3% in 2011 as a direct consequence of the civil conflict and its economic disruptions.
• Under the presidency of Bashar Assad, Syria's national debt as a percentage of GDP significantly decreased from 152.09% in the year 2000 to 30.02% by 2010.

• Prior to the outbreak of the Syrian civil war, the Syrian government actively sought to alleviate its substantial foreign debt burden through bilateral debt rescheduling agreements with major European creditors, including Germany, France, and Russia.
• In December 2004, Syria and Poland reached a debt settlement agreement whereby Syria agreed to pay $27 million out of a total outstanding debt of $261.7 million owed to Poland.
• In January 2005, Syria and Russia signed a landmark debt restructuring deal that resulted in the forgiveness of nearly 75% of Syria's debt to Russia, which amounted to approximately $13 billion.
• Following the 2005 agreement, Syria's remaining debt to Russia was reduced to less than €3 billion (equivalent to just over $3.6 billion).

• The terms of the Russia-Syria agreement stipulated that half of the remaining debt would be repaid over the subsequent 10 years, while the other half would be deposited into Russian accounts held within Syrian banks.
• The funds deposited in Russian accounts in Syria were designated for use in Russian investment projects within Syria and for the purchase of Syrian products.

• Later in 2005, Syria concluded a debt settlement agreement with Slovakia and the Czech Republic, agreeing to settle an estimated total debt of $1.6 billion through a one-time payment of $150 million.
• Agriculture is a high priority in Syria's economic development plans, aimed at achieving food self-sufficiency, increasing export earnings, and halting rural out-migration.

• Prior to the civil war, sustained capital investment, infrastructure development, subsidies of inputs, and price supports enabled Syria to transition from a net importer to an exporter of cotton, fruits, vegetables, and other foodstuffs.
• A key factor in this agricultural turnaround was the government's investment in large irrigation systems located in northern and northeastern Syria.

• As of 2009, the agriculture sector employed approximately 17% of Syria's labor force and generated about 21% of the GDP, with livestock accounting for 16% of agricultural output and fruit and grains contributing more than 40%.
• In 2015, Syria's main agricultural exports included spice seeds valued at $83.2 million and apples and pears valued at $53.2 million.
• Most agricultural land in Syria is privately owned, which has been crucial to the sector's success.
• Syria's total land area is 196,000 km² (76,000 sq mi), of which about 28% is cultivated; 21% of cultivated land is irrigated.
• Most irrigated land is classified as "strategic," subject to significant state intervention including pricing, subsidies, and marketing controls.

• "Strategic" crops such as wheat, barley, and sugar beets must be sold to state marketing boards at fixed prices, often above world market prices, to support farmers but at a considerable cost to the state budget.
• Wheat is the most widely grown arable crop, while cotton is the most important cash crop; cotton was Syria's largest single export before the rise of the oil sector.
• The total area planted with cotton has declined due to increasing water shortages and outdated, inefficient irrigation techniques.
• Grain outputs, including wheat, are often underutilized because of inadequate storage facilities.
• Water scarcity and energy shortages are pervasive challenges facing Syria's agricultural sector.
• The government's decision to liberalize fertilizer prices led to increases ranging between 100% and 400%, further complicating agricultural production costs.
• In 2008, drought conditions were severe, but the situation improved slightly in 2009, with wheat and barley production roughly doubling compared to 2008.
• Despite improved production in 2009, the livelihoods of up to 1 million agricultural workers were threatened, prompting the United Nations to launch an emergency appeal for $20.2 million.
• Wheat has been among the most affected crops, and for the first time in two decades, Syria shifted from being a net exporter to a net importer of wheat.
• During the civil war beginning in 2011, the Syrian government issued a tender for 100,000 metric tonnes of wheat, one of the few trade products exempt from economic sanctions.
• Less than 2.7% of Syria's land area is forested, with only a portion being commercially viable.
• Limited forestry activities are concentrated in the higher elevations of mountains near the coast, where rainfall is more abundant.
• As of 2022, captagon was the most valuable export product of Ba'athist Syria, serving as a critical source of income for the Assad regime.
• In 2021, the total value of captagon drug shipments sold was approximately $5.7 billion.
• The majority of these drug shipments were dismantled by the new Syrian caretaker government in January 2025.
• Phosphates constitute the primary mineral resource exploited in Syria, with estimated reserves of approximately 1,700 million tons.
• In the early 1990s, Syrian phosphate production experienced a significant decline due to reduced global demand and falling prices.
• Following this decline, phosphate output in Syria increased to exceed 2.4 million tons.
• In 2009, Syria accounted for about 1.9% of the global phosphate rock production, ranking as the ninth largest producer worldwide.

• Besides phosphates, Syria produces several other major minerals including cement, gypsum, industrial sand (silica), marble, natural crude asphalt, nitrogen fertilizer, phosphate fertilizer, salt, steel, and volcanic tuff.
• The majority of these other minerals are produced primarily for domestic use rather than for export purposes.
• In 2010, Syria accounted for just 0.5% of global oil production, marking it as a relatively small oil producer on the world stage.
• Despite its modest production scale, oil remains a major pillar of the Syrian economy, significantly contributing to government revenues and export income.
• The International Monetary Fund projected that oil sales in 2010 would generate $3.2 billion for the Syrian government, representing 25.1% of the state's total revenue for that year.
• According to the 2009 Syria Report by the Oxford Business Group, in 2008 the oil sector contributed 23% of government revenues, underscoring its fiscal importance.
• In 2008, oil accounted for 20% of Syria’s exports, indicating its critical role in the country’s trade balance.
• The oil sector represented 22% of Syria’s GDP in 2008, highlighting its substantial impact on the overall economy.
• Syria exported approximately 150,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil in 2008, with oil constituting the majority of the country’s export income during that period.
• In 2001, Syria reportedly produced 23.3 billion kilowatt hours (kWh) of electricity and consumed 21.6 billion kWh, indicating a surplus in production over consumption.

• As of January 2002, Syria's total installed electric generating capacity was 7.6 gigawatts (GW), with primary energy sources being fuel oil and natural gas, complemented by 1.5 GW generated from hydroelectric power.
• A regional electric power grid network totaling 45 GW, linking Syria, Egypt, and Jordan, was completed in March 2001, enhancing regional power connectivity.

• The Syrian government prioritizes electric supply capacity as a key national objective and planned to add 3,000 megawatts (MW) of power generating capacity by 2010, with an estimated investment cost of US$2 billion; however, progress has been hindered by a lack of investment capital.
• Syrian power plants have been undergoing intensive maintenance, and four new generating plants have been constructed to improve electricity production capabilities.

• The power distribution network in Syria faces significant challenges, with transmission losses estimated to be as high as 25 percent of total generated capacity, primarily due to poor quality wires and transformer stations.
• A project aimed at expanding and upgrading the power transmission network was scheduled for completion in 2005, intended to address the high transmission losses and improve distribution efficiency.

• In May 2009, it was reported that the Islamic Development Bank and the Syrian government signed an agreement whereby the bank would provide a €100 million loan specifically for the expansion of the Deir Ali power station in Syria.
• Syria initially planned to build a VVER-440 nuclear reactor but abandoned these plans following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.
• In the early 2000s, Syria revived its nuclear program ambitions and entered negotiations with Russia to construct a nuclear facility.
• The proposed nuclear facility discussed with Russia was intended to comprise both a nuclear power plant and a seawater atomic desalination plant.

• In 2010, Syria's industrial sector—which encompasses mining, manufacturing, construction, and petroleum—contributed 27.3 percent to the country's gross domestic product (GDP) and employed approximately 16 percent of the labor force.
• The primary industrial products of Syria include petroleum, textiles, food processing, beverages, tobacco, phosphate rock mining, cement, oil seeds crushing, and automobile assembly.

• Until the 1990s, Syria's manufacturing sector was predominantly state-controlled; however, economic reforms during that decade permitted increased participation from both local and foreign private sectors.

• Despite reforms, private sector involvement in manufacturing remains limited due to several constraints: insufficient investment capital, regulated input and output pricing, complex customs and foreign exchange regulations, and inadequate marketing infrastructure.
• Real estate represents one of the few domestic investment opportunities offering realistic and secure returns, largely because land prices are not regulated by the state.
• The construction sector's activity levels tend to reflect broader economic fluctuations, indicating its sensitivity to overall economic conditions.

• The enactment of Investment Law No. 10 in 1991, which allowed foreign investment in selected sectors, initiated a significant economic revival, evidenced by real-term growth increases during 2001 and 2002.
• In 2017, the services sector constituted 60.4% of Syria's gross domestic product (GDP), indicating its dominant role in the national economy.
• The services sector employed 67% of the Syrian labor force, including government employees, as recorded in 2008, highlighting its significance as the primary source of employment.
• In May 2009, reports indicated a sharp increase in office prices in Damascus, reflecting a notable surge in the real estate market within the capital city.
• The Central Bank of Syria commenced operations in 1959 and is responsible for controlling all foreign exchange and trade transactions, prioritizing lending to the public sector.

• Since May 2004, the Central Bank of Syria has been subjected to U.S. sanctions, which accused the bank of money laundering; these sanctions include a ban on transactions between U.S. financial institutions and the Central Bank, potentially increasing the role of Lebanese and European banks as intermediaries for U.S. dollar transfers.
• Additional sanctions on the Central Bank have been imposed by the United States, European Union, Arab League, and Turkey due to the Syrian Civil War.

• Syria’s banking sector includes six specialized state-owned banks: the Central Bank of Syria, Commercial Bank of Syria, Agricultural Co-Operative Bank, Industrial Bank, Popular Credit Bank, and Real Estate Bank; each bank serves a specific sector and extends funds and accepts deposits accordingly.

• The Industrial Bank primarily focuses on the public sector but is undercapitalized, causing the private sector to often seek banking services abroad, which is more expensive and inefficient for industrial financing.
• It is estimated that Syrian nationals have deposited approximately US$6 billion in Lebanese banks, reflecting capital flight and lack of domestic banking options.
• In the 2000s, Syria initiated financial sector reforms, including legalizing private banks in 2001 and opening the Damascus Securities Exchange in March 2009.

• Foreign banks were granted licenses starting in December 2002 under Law 28 of March 2001, which allows the establishment of private and joint-venture banks; foreigners may own up to 49% of a bank but cannot hold a controlling stake.
• By January 2010, 13 private banks had been established in Syria, including two Islamic banks, marking growth in the nascent private banking sector.

• Syria gradually loosened foreign exchange controls: in 2003, it repealed a law criminalizing private sector use of foreign currencies; in 2005, licensed private banks were allowed to sell limited foreign currency amounts to Syrian citizens and the private sector for import financing.

• In October 2009, Syria further relaxed currency transfer restrictions by permitting Syrians traveling abroad to withdraw up to US$10,000 from Syrian pound accounts, effectively allowing local banks to open accounts capped at US$10,000 for international payment card use, with monthly withdrawal limits of US$10,000 while abroad.
• To encourage investment and improve credit access, the government in 2007 allowed investors to obtain loans from foreign banks and repay them through local banks using project proceeds.
• In February 2008, investors were permitted to receive foreign currency loans from local private banks to finance capital investments.

• Syria maintains a fixed exchange rate system with two official rates: one used for the budget and official transactions such as imports and customs, and a second, daily rate set by the Central Bank for all other financial transactions.
• A 2006 law authorized the operation of private money exchange companies, although a small black market for foreign currency persists.

• Since the onset of the Syrian Civil War in 2011, significant capital flight has occurred to neighboring countries, exacerbated by sanctions imposed by the United States, Canada, European Union, Arab League, and Turkey.
• The Syrian currency, the Syrian pound (SYP), has experienced severe depreciation, with the official exchange rate falling from £S 47 per US$1 before the civil war to £S 1,256 per US$1 by June 2020.
• The exchange rate used for money transfers was approximately £S 1,250 per US$1, while the non-official (black market) exchange rate plunged to around £S 4,000 per US$1 by March 2021.
• Tourism in Syria has experienced a significant decline due to the Syrian Civil War and the resulting refugee crisis, which have severely disrupted the country's stability and safety for visitors.
• The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, beginning in March 2020, further exacerbated the downturn in Syria's tourism sector by restricting travel and reducing international tourist arrivals.

• International economic sanctions imposed on Syria have negatively affected the tourism industry by limiting foreign investment, access to international markets, and the overall economic environment conducive to tourism development.

• The sharp depreciation of the Syrian pound has also contributed to the decline in tourism by increasing costs and economic uncertainty, thereby discouraging both domestic and international tourists from visiting Syria.
• Syria has an approximate population of 21 million people, with a government-reported population growth rate of 2.37%.
• Demographically, 65% of Syria's population is under the age of 35, and more than 40% are under the age of 15.
• Each year, over 200,000 new job seekers enter the Syrian labor market, but the economy has been unable to absorb this influx adequately.
• In 2017, the Syrian labor force was estimated to be about 3.767 million individuals.
• Employment distribution in 2008 was approximately 67% in the services sector (including government employment), 17% in agriculture, and 16% in industry.
• Government and public sector employees make up about 30% of the total labor force and receive very low salaries and wages.
• Official Syrian government statistics reported an unemployment rate of 12.6% in 2009; however, independent sources estimate the actual unemployment rate to be closer to 20%.
• Approximately 70% of Syria's workforce earns less than US$100 per month.
• Anecdotal evidence indicates that a significant number of Syrians seek employment across the border in Lebanon, exceeding official figures.
• The Unemployment Commission (UC) was established in 2002 with the mandate to create several hundred thousand jobs over a five-year period.
• As of June 2009, reports indicated that around 700,000 Syrian households, equating to about 3.5 million people, had no income.
• Syrian government officials have acknowledged that the economy is not growing sufficiently to generate enough new jobs annually to keep pace with population growth.
• The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) announced in 2005 that 30% of the Syrian population lives in poverty, with 11.4% living below the subsistence level.
• The Ministry of Social Affairs and Labour holds responsibility for labor-related issues in Syria.
• A report by Strategic Foresight Group, an India-based think tank, calculated the opportunity cost of conflict for the Middle East from 1991 to 2010 at US$12 trillion in 2006 dollars.
• Syria's share of this opportunity cost was US$152 billion, which is more than four times the projected 2010 GDP of US$36 billion.
• According to the Syrian Center for Policy Research in March 2015, nearly three million Syrians had lost their jobs due to the civil war by that time.
• The job losses caused the primary source of income to be lost for more than 12 million people in Syria.
• Unemployment levels in Syria surged from 14.9 percent in 2011 to 57.7 percent by the end of 2014.
• As a consequence of the conflict and economic decline, 4 in 5 Syrians were living in poverty by 2015.
• Approximately 30 percent of the Syrian population was living in "abject poverty" in 2015, frequently unable to meet basic household food needs.
• An estimate from 2023 indicated that 90 percent of the Syrian population was living below the poverty threshold.
